title: Building Agents
code: library(aisdk)  # Create a Math Agent math_agent <- create_agent(   name = "MathAgent",   description = "Performs arithmetic calculations and mathematical reasoning",   system_prompt = "You are a math assistant. return only numerical results." )  print(math_agent)

title: Building Agents
text: run agent, use $run() method. need provide model (string ID).
code: model <- create_openai()$language_model("gpt-4o")  result <- math_agent$run(   task = "What is the square root of 144?",   model = model )  print(result$text)

title: Building Agents
text: Agents can share memories environments ChatSession. powerful multi-agent workflows.
code: # Create a shared session session <- create_chat_session(   model = model,   system_prompt = "You are a helpful assistant." )  # Store some shared data session$set_memory("project_name", "Apollo") env <- session$get_envir() env$data <- data.frame(x = 1:10, y = rnorm(10))  # Run agent with session context # The agent can now access 'data' if it has tools to do so,  # or conceptually if we inject it into the prompt. result <- math_agent$run(   task = "Analyze the project data",   session = session,   model = model )

title: Building Agents
text: aisdk comes pre-built specialized agents: create_coder_agent(): Optimized reading writing code. create_planner_agent(): Optimized breaking tasks. create_visualizer_agent(): Optimized creating plots (ggplot2).

title: Enterprise Operations
text: Telemetry hooks allow trace execution flows.
code: library(aisdk)  # Create standard telemetry telemetry <- create_telemetry(trace_id = "request-123") hooks <- telemetry$as_hooks()  # Pass hooks to generation generate_text(   model = "openai:gpt-4o",    prompt = "Hello",    hooks = hooks )

title: Enterprise Operations
text: can intercept sensitive tool calls (like file writing) require approval. Common mistake: assigning hooks$on_tool_approval <- ... fails â€œadd bindings locked environmentâ€ HookHandler R6 object. Always assign inside hooks list.
code: # Permission hook: only allow "read_file" automatically # "write_file" will trigger a request for approval (or denial in non-interactive) perm_hook <- create_permission_hook(   mode = "escalate",    allowlist = c("read_file")  )  # Combine with other hooks hooks$hooks$on_tool_approval <- perm_hook$hooks$on_tool_approval

title: Enterprise Operations
code: Wrap tools with `cache_tool()` to memoize their results. The `...` in the example is a placeholder and cannot be run directly in the console. slow_tool <- tool(..., execute = function(args) { Sys.sleep(5); ... })  # For example, we have a time-consuming tool `slow_tool` that sleeps for 5 seconds and then returns the input parameter `x`. slow_tool <- tool(   name = "slow_tool",   description = "Sleep 5 seconds and return x",   parameters = z_object(x = z_number("Input number")),   execute = function(args) { Sys.sleep(5); args$x } )  # Cached version fast_tool <- cache_tool(slow_tool)  # First call: 5 seconds fast_tool$run(list(x = 1))  # Second call: Instant fast_tool$run(list(x = 1))

title: Get Started with aisdk
text: First, load library set API keys environment variables.
code: library(aisdk)  # RECOMMENDED: Set in your .Renviron file Sys.setenv(OPENAI_API_KEY = "sk-...") Sys.setenv(ANTHROPIC_API_KEY = "sk-ant-...")

title: Get Started with aisdk
text: can create model provider using specific factory functions unified registry syntax.
code: # Option A: Factory Function openai <- create_openai() model <- openai$language_model("gpt-4o")  # Option B: Registry Syntax (if provider is registered) registry <- get_default_registry() registry$register("openai", create_openai()) # model <- "openai:gpt-4o"

title: Get Started with aisdk
text: Use generate_text() simple request-response interactions. can also use system prompt set behavior:
code: response <- generate_text(   model = model,   prompt = "Explain the difference between lapply and sapply in R." )  cat(response$text) response <- generate_text(   model = model,   system = "You are a concise data science instructor.",   prompt = "What is a tibble?" )

title: Get Started with aisdk
code: stream_text(   model = model,   prompt = "Write a haiku about CRAN.",   callback = function(chunk, done) {     if (!done) cat(chunk)   } )

title: Get Started with aisdk
text: Switching Anthropic simple changing model creation step. rest code remains .
code: # Create Anthropic provider anthropic <- create_anthropic() model <- anthropic$language_model("claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022")  # Generate text (SAME API!) response <- generate_text(   model = model,   prompt = "Explain R6 classes briefly." ) cat(response$text)

title: Shiny Integration
text: Use aiChatUI() aiChatServer() add chat interface.
code: library(shiny) library(aisdk)  ui <- fluidPage(   aiChatUI("chat") )  server <- function(input, output, session) {   aiChatServer("chat", model = "openai:gpt-4o") }  shinyApp(ui, server)

title: Shiny Integration
text: can give AI tools modify reactiveValues, effectively letting control app.

title: Shiny Integration
text: Use reactive_tool() define tools can read/write values.
code: change_color <- reactive_tool(   name = "change_color",   description = "Change the plot color",   parameters = z_object(color = z_string()),   execute = function(rv, session, color) {     rv$plot_color <- color     paste("Changed color to", color)   } )

title: Shiny Integration
text: Now user can say â€œChange plot redâ€, AI execute tool, updating Shiny app instantly.
code: server <- function(input, output, session) {   # ... rv definition ...      # Wrap tools with current session context   tools <- wrap_reactive_tools(list(change_color), rv, session)      # Provide context so AI "sees" the current state   get_context <- reactive({     list(current_color = rv$plot_color)   })    aiChatServer(     "chat",     model = "openai:gpt-4o",     tools = tools,     context = get_context   ) }

title: Connectivity (MCP)
text: can connect MCP-compliant server (Node.js, Python, R) use tools.

title: Connectivity (MCP)
text: example connects official GitHub MCP server let AI interact repositories. Node.js installed (run server). GITHUB_TOKEN environment variable set. Connect Client: Use AI: Convert MCP tools aisdk Tools pass model. Cleanup:
code: library(aisdk)  # Start the Node.js GitHub server github_client <- create_mcp_client(   command = "npx",   args = c("-y", "@modelcontextprotocol/server-github"),   env = c(GITHUB_PERSONAL_ACCESS_TOKEN = Sys.getenv("GITHUB_TOKEN")) )  # List available tools tools <- github_client$list_tools() print(tools[[1]]$name)  # e.g., "create_issue", "list_pull_requests"... sdk_tools <- github_client$as_sdk_tools()  # Create a session (manages history and tool loops) # max_steps=10 enables automatic ReAct loop for tool calling chat <- create_chat_session(   model = "openai:gpt-4o",   tools = sdk_tools,   max_steps = 10 )  # Option 1: Run programmatically result <- chat$send("List my recent pull requests") print(result$text)  # Option 2: Run interactively with streaming # console_chat(chat) github_client$close()

title: Chat Sessions
code: library(aisdk)  chat <- create_chat_session(   model = "openai:gpt-4o",   system_prompt = "You are a helpful R expert." )

title: Chat Sessions
code: # 1st turn chat$send("What is R?")  # 2nd turn - Model remembers context chat$send("Who created it?")

title: Chat Sessions
text: can switch underlying model mid-conversation. history preserved.
code: # Switch to a cheaper model for simple queries chat$switch_model("openai:gpt-4o-mini")

title: Chat Sessions
text: Sessions can saved loaded, preserving full conversation history.
code: # Save to R native format chat$save("my_session.rds")  # Load later new_chat <- load_chat_session("my_session.rds")

title: Chat Sessions
text: interactive use R console, use console_chat().

title: Skill System
text: skill directory containing: - SKILL.md: Metadata (YAML header) instructions. - scripts/: R scripts can executed. Example File: greeting/SKILL.md Example File: greeting/scripts/greet.R
code: --- name: greeting_skill description: Generates greetings --- # Instructions Use the `greet.R` script to greet users. # Expects args$name sprintf("Hello, %s!", args$name)

title: Skill System
text: Create Registry: Point skills folder. Generate Skills: Pass registry generate_text.
code: library(aisdk) registry <- create_skill_registry("./my_skills") # The model will see the skill descriptions and can decide to load them result <- generate_text(   model = "openai:gpt-4o",   prompt = "Use the greeting skill to say hi to Alice",   skills = registry,   max_steps = 3  )  # Under the hood: # 1. Model sees "greeting_skill" available. # 2. Model calls "load_skill('greeting_skill')". # 3. Model sees "greet.R" script. # 4. Model calls "execute_skill_script('greet.R', name='Alice')". # 5. Model returns result.

title: Structured Outputs
code: library(aisdk)  # Define schema article_schema <- z_object(   title = z_string(description = "The main title"),   sentiment = z_enum(c("positive", "negative", "neutral")),   keywords = z_array(z_string(), max_items = 5) )  # Generate object result <- generate_object(   model = "openai:gpt-4o",   prompt = "R is an amazing language for data science!",   schema = article_schema )  # Access typed results print(result$object$title) print(result$object$sentiment)

title: Structured Outputs
text: aisdk includes special z_dataframe() helper requests list objects, perfect extracting tables.
code: # Define table schema gene_schema <- z_dataframe(   gene_name = z_string(description = "Name of the gene"),   expression_level = z_number(description = "Expression value"),   significant = z_boolean(description = "p < 0.05") )  result <- generate_object(   model = "openai:gpt-4o",   prompt = "Extract data: gene BRCA1 (2.5), TP53 (-1.8), MYC (0.3)",   schema = gene_schema )  # Convert to R data frame library(dplyr) df <- bind_rows(result$object) print(df)

title: Structured Outputs
code: analysis_schema <- z_object(   experiment = z_object(     name = z_string(),     date = z_string()   ),   results = z_array(     z_object(       metric = z_string(),       value = z_number()     )   ) )

title: Using Tools
text: define tool using tool() function. also need define schema toolâ€™s expected arguments using helper functions (z_object, z_string, z_number, etc.).

title: Using Tools
code: library(aisdk)  # 1. Define the input schema weather_schema <- z_object(   location = z_string(description = "The city name, e.g., 'Tokyo'"),   unit = z_enum(c("celsius", "fahrenheit"), description = "Temperature unit") )  # 2. Create the tool get_weather <- tool(   name = "get_weather",   description = "Get the current weather for a city",   parameters = weather_schema,   execute = function(args) {     # In a real app, call an API here     # For demo, returning mock string     location <- args$location     unit <- args$unit %||% "celsius"          paste0("Weather in ", location, ": 22Â°C (", unit, ")")   } )

title: Using Tools
code: model <- create_openai()$language_model("gpt-4o")  result <- generate_text(   model = model,   prompt = "What's the weather like in Paris?",   tools = list(get_weather) )  # If the model decided to call the tool, the result text will contain the final answer # after the tool was executed and the result fed back to the model. cat(result$text)

what: AI SDK for R - Unified Interface for AI Model Providers
title: AI SDK for R - Unified Interface for AI Model Providers
text: aisdk production-grade framework building AI-powered applications R. provides unified interface multiple model providers (OpenAI, Anthropic), powerful agentic system, seamless integration R ecosystem (Shiny, RMarkdown, Quarto).

title: AI SDK for R - Unified Interface for AI Model Providers
text: Genesis V1: One-line execution auto-discovery: genesis("Analyze iris dataset") Genesis V2: Iterative refinement quality checks: genesis_v2("Complex task", auto_refine = TRUE) Automatic agent discovery team assembly AI-powered team composition via Architect agent Quality evaluation automatic improvement Smart caching performance Unified API: Switch OpenAI Anthropic models single line code. CoderAgent: Writes edits code. PlannerAgent: Breaks complex problems. Multi-Agent Teams: Coordinate multiple specialized agents Tool System: Turn R function AI-callable tool automatic schema generation. Structured Outputs: Generate type-safe JSON, data frames, complex objects. Chat Sessions: Stateful conversation management history tracking. Enterprise Ops: Telemetry, hooks, cost tracking, MCP (Model Context Protocol) support.

text: Skills system allows package specialized knowledge tools can dynamically loaded agents. saves context window space keeps agents focused. Use Demo Skill: Example Output:
code: # Initialize the registry and tools registry <- create_skill_registry(system.file("skills", package = "aisdk")) skill_tools <- create_skill_tools(registry)  # Create an agent analyst <- create_agent(   name = "DataAnalyst",   description = "A data analysis agent",   system_prompt = "You are an expert data analyst. Use the available skills to help the user.",   tools = skill_tools # <--- Pass the list of tools, NOT the registry )  # Run the agent analyst$stream("Load the data_analysis skill and summarize the mtcars dataset.", model = model) â”€â”€ â¯ Thinking... â”€ â”€  The user wants me to: â”€  1. Load the data_analysis skill â”€  2. Summarize the mtcars dataset â”€ â”€  Let me start by loading the skill to see what scripts are available. â”€ â”€â”€ âœ” Done thinking (5 lines)    (â„¹ Hide with options(aisdk.show_thinking = FALSE))   I'll help you load the data_analysis skill and summarize the mtcars dataset. Let me start by loading the skill. â„¹ Calling tool load_skill {"skill_name":"data_analysis"} âœ” Tool load_skill returned: "# Instructions Use the `analyze.R` script to analyze datasets.  ## Available Datasets - iris: Fisher's Iris dataset (150 observations, 5 variables) - mtcars: Motor Trend Car Road Tests (32 observat..."â”€â”€ â¯ Thinking... â”€ â”€  Now I can see that the data_analysis skill has an analyze.R script that can analyze datasets. The mtcars dataset is available, and I should use the analyze.R script with the dataset parameter set to "mtcars". I'll use the default top_n value of 5 as shown in the example. â”€ â”€â”€ âœ” Done thinking (1 lines)    (â„¹ Hide with options(aisdk.show_thinking = FALSE))   â–¶ Calling tool execute_skill_script {"skill_name":"data_analysis","script_name":"analyze.R","args":{"dataset":"mtcars","top_n":5}} âœ” Tool execute_skill_script returned: "Dataset: mtcars Dimensions: 32 rows x 11 cols Columns: mpg, cyl, disp, hp, drat, wt, qsec, vs, am, gear, carb Numeric Summary: mpg: min=10.40, max=33.90, mean=20.09 cyl: min=4.00, max=8.00, mean=..."â”€â”€ â¯ Thinking... â”€ â”€  Great! I've successfully loaded the data_analysis skill and analyzed the mtcars dataset. The output provides a comprehensive summary of the dataset including: â”€ â”€  1. Dataset dimensions (32 rows x 11 columns) â”€  2. Column names â”€  3. Numeric summary statistics (min, max, mean) for all variables â”€  4. First 5 rows of the dataset â”€ â”€  This gives a good overview of the mtcars dataset, which contains data about Motor Trend car road tests with various performance and design characteristics for 32 different car models. â”€ â”€â”€ âœ” Done thinking (8 lines)    (â„¹ Hide with options(aisdk.show_thinking = FALSE))   I've successfully loaded the data_analysis skill and analyzed the mtcars dataset. Here's a summary:   â”€â”€ Dataset Overview â”€â”€- Name: mtcars (Motor Trend Car Road Tests) - Dimensions: 32 observations Ã— 11 variables - Variables: mpg, cyl, disp, hp, drat, wt, qsec, vs, am, gear, carb  â”€â”€ Key Statistics Summary â”€â”€ | Variable | Min   | Max    | Mean   | Description                     | | -------- | ----- | ------ | ------ | ------------------------------- | | mpg      | 10.40 | 33.90  | 20.09  | Miles per gallon                | | cyl      | 4.00  | 8.00   | 6.19   | Number of cylinders             | | disp     | 71.10 | 472.00 | 230.72 | Displacement (cu.in.)           | | hp       | 52.00 | 335.00 | 146.69 | Gross horsepower                | | drat     | 2.76  | 4.93   | 3.60   | Rear axle ratio                 | | wt       | 1.51  | 5.42   | 3.22   | Weight (1000 lbs)               | | qsec     | 14.50 | 22.90  | 17.85  | 1/4 mile time                   | | vs       | 0.00  | 1.00   | 0.44   | Engine type (0=V, 1=Straight)   | | am       | 0.00  | 1.00   | 0.41   | Transmission (0=Auto, 1=Manual) | | gear     | 3.00  | 5.00   | 3.69   | Number of forward gears         | | carb     | 1.00  | 8.00   | 2.81   | Number of carburetors           |  â”€â”€ Sample Data (First 5 Rows) â”€â”€The dataset includes classic cars like the Mazda RX4 (21.0 mpg), Datsun 710 (22.8 mpg), and Hornet models, showing a range of performance characteristics from fuel economy to horsepower and weight.  This dataset is commonly used for regression analysis and exploring relationships between car design parameters and fuel efficiency.

Defaults https://api.openai.com/v1. organization Optional OpenAI organization ID. project Optional OpenAI project ID. headers Optional additional headers. name Optional provider name override (compatible APIs). disable_stream_options Disable stream_options parameter (providers like Volcengine support ).

title: Create OpenAI Provider â€” create_openai
text: SDK provides unified max_tokens parameter automatically maps correct API field based model API type: Chat API (standard models): max_tokens -> max_tokens Chat API (o1/o3 models): max_tokens -> max_completion_tokens Responses API: max_tokens -> max_output_tokens (total: reasoning + answer) advanced users need fine-grained control: max_completion_tokens: Explicitly set completion tokens (Chat API, o1/o3) max_output_tokens: Explicitly set total output limit (Responses API) max_answer_tokens: Limit answer , excluding reasoning (Responses API, Volcengine-specific)

title: Create OpenAI Provider â€” create_openai
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Basic usage with Chat Completions API openai <- create_openai(api_key = "sk-...") model <- openai$language_model("gpt-4o") result <- generate_text(model, "Hello!")  # Using Responses API for reasoning models openai <- create_openai() model <- openai$responses_model("o1") result <- generate_text(model, "Solve this math problem...") print(result$reasoning)  # Access chain-of-thought  # Smart model selection (auto-detects best API) model <- openai$smart_model("o3-mini")  # Uses Responses API model <- openai$smart_model("gpt-4o")   # Uses Chat Completions API  # Token limits - unified interface # For standard models: limits generated content result <- model$generate(messages = msgs, max_tokens = 1000)  # For o1/o3 models: automatically maps to max_completion_tokens model_o1 <- openai$language_model("o1") result <- model_o1$generate(messages = msgs, max_tokens = 2000)  # For Responses API: automatically maps to max_output_tokens (total limit) model_resp <- openai$responses_model("o1") result <- model_resp$generate(messages = msgs, max_tokens = 2000)  # Advanced: explicitly control answer-only limit (Volcengine Responses API) result <- model_resp$generate(messages = msgs, max_answer_tokens = 500)  # Multi-turn conversation with Responses API model <- openai$responses_model("o1") result1 <- generate_text(model, "What is 2+2?") result2 <- generate_text(model, "Now multiply that by 3")  # Remembers context model$reset()  # Start fresh conversation  # For Volcengine/Ark API volcengine <- create_openai(   api_key = Sys.getenv("ARK_API_KEY"),   base_url = "https://ark.cn-beijing.volces.com/api/v3",   name = "volcengine",   disable_stream_options = TRUE ) } # }

what: Token Limit Parameters for Volcengine Responses API
title: Create Volcengine/Ark Provider â€” create_volcengine
text: Volcengine's Responses API two mutually exclusive token limit parameters: max_output_tokens: Total limit including reasoning + answer (default mapping) max_tokens (API level): Answer-limit, excluding reasoning SDK's unified max_tokens parameter maps max_output_tokens default, safe choice prevent runaway reasoning costs. advanced users want answer-limits: Use max_answer_tokens parameter explicitly set answer-limit Use max_output_tokens parameter explicitly set total limit

title: Create Volcengine/Ark Provider â€” create_volcengine
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ volcengine <- create_volcengine()  # Chat API (standard models) model <- volcengine$language_model("doubao-1-5-pro-256k-250115") result <- generate_text(model, "ä½ å¥½")  # Responses API (reasoning models like DeepSeek) model <- volcengine$responses_model("deepseek-r1-250120")  # Default: max_tokens limits total output (reasoning + answer) result <- model$generate(messages = msgs, max_tokens = 2000)  # Advanced: limit only the answer part (reasoning can be longer) result <- model$generate(messages = msgs, max_answer_tokens = 500)  # Advanced: explicitly set total limit result <- model$generate(messages = msgs, max_output_tokens = 3000) } # }

title: Generate Text â€” generate_text
text: Generate text using language model. primary high-level function non-streaming text generation. tools provided max_steps > 1, function automatically execute tool calls feed results back LLM ReAct-style loop LLM produces final response max_steps reached.

title: Generate Text â€” generate_text
code: generate_text(   model,   prompt,   system = NULL,   temperature = 0.7,   max_tokens = NULL,   tools = NULL,   max_steps = 1,   skills = NULL,   session = NULL,   hooks = NULL,   registry = NULL,   ... )

title: Generate Text â€” generate_text
text: model Either LanguageModelV1 object, string ID like "openai:gpt-4o". prompt character string prompt, list messages. system Optional system prompt. temperature Sampling temperature (0-2). Default 0.7. max_tokens Maximum tokens generate. tools Optional list Tool objects function calling. max_steps Maximum number generation steps (tool execution loops). Default 1 (single generation, automatic tool execution). Set higher values (e.g., 5) enable automatic tool execution. skills Optional path skills directory, SkillRegistry object. provided, skill tools auto-injected skill summaries added system prompt. session Optional ChatSession object. provided, tool executions run session's environment, enabling cross-agent data sharing. hooks Optional HookHandler object intercepting events. registry Optional ProviderRegistry use (defaults global registry). ... Additional arguments passed model.

title: Generate Text â€” generate_text
text: GenerateResult object text optionally tool_calls. max_steps > 1 tools used, result includes: steps: Number steps taken all_tool_calls: List tool calls made across steps

title: Generate Text â€” generate_text
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Using hooks my_hooks <- create_hooks(   on_generation_start = function(model, prompt, tools) message("Starting..."),   on_tool_start = function(tool, args) message("Calling tool ", tool$name) ) result <- generate_text(model, "...", hooks = my_hooks) } # }

title: Create a Tool â€” tool
text: name Unique tool name (used LLM call tool). description Description tool's purpose. descriptive help LLM understand use tool. parameters z_object schema defining expected parameters. Use z_object() z_string(), z_number(), etc. define schema. execute R function implements tool logic. function receives single list argument containing parameters.

title: Create a Tool â€” tool
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Define a weather tool get_weather <- tool(   name = "get_weather",   description = "Get the current weather for a location",   parameters = z_object(     location = z_string(description = "The city name, e.g., 'Beijing'"),     unit = z_enum(c("celsius", "fahrenheit"), description = "Temperature unit")   ),   execute = function(args) {     # In real usage, call a weather API here     paste("Weather in", args$location, "is 22 degrees", args$unit)   } )  # Use with generate_text result <- generate_text(   model = "openai:gpt-4o",   prompt = "What's the weather in Tokyo?",   tools = list(get_weather) ) } # }
